entry.title: Venue Analytics: A Simple Alternative to Citation-Based Metrics

link.title: Venue Analytics: A Simple Alternative to Citation-Based Metrics

entry.content: A bibliometric/scientometric project. Our main two results are a method of assigning value to all venues in computer science and a method to organize them into distinct subfields, all without using citation data. The resulting venue scores can be used to rank universities’ by scholarly output, and produce a responsive author-level metric.
entry.summary: A bibliometric/scientometric project. Our main two results are a method of assigning value to all venues in computer science and a method to organize them into distinct subfields, all without using citation data. The resulting venue scores can be used to rank universities’ by scholarly output, and produce a responsive author-level metric.

entry.title: Direct Fitting of Gaussian Mixture Models

link.title: Direct Fitting of Gaussian Mixture Models

entry.content: A formulation for fitting Gaussian Mixture Models (GMMs) directly to geometric objects, such as a triangular mesh. This method produces more robust results and produces an improvement in 3D registration for both meshes and RGB-D frames.
entry.summary: A formulation for fitting Gaussian Mixture Models (GMMs) directly to geometric objects, such as a triangular mesh. This method produces more robust results and produces an improvement in 3D registration for both meshes and RGB-D frames.

entry.title: Dice Stacking: A Dynamic Manipulation Task

link.title: Dice Stacking: A Dynamic Manipulation Task

entry.content:
With Hunter Goforth, we designed a manipulation task and solved it with imitation learning.

With Chris Atkeson and Alex Spitzer. Using optimizers to match an observed trajectory.
entry.summary: With Hunter Goforth, we designed a manipulation task and solved it with imitation learning.

entry.title: A Maze Bot
entry.content:
Making a 6-DoF PUMA arm solve a maze with real-time vision and tracking.

The final project combined real-time vision, planning, and control into a success project for our Experimental Robotics Graduate class.

CS225A Paper

Short demo video on YouTube

Longer demo video on YouTube
entry.summary: Making a 6-DoF PUMA arm solve a maze with real-time vision and tracking.

entry.title: Learning Implicit Communication Strategies
entry.content:
Work with Aaron Goodman on used reinforcement learning to discover implicit collusion strategies in the context of an iterated prisoner’s dilemma.

We analyzed the techniques that are learned to understand how agents can develop signaling mechanisms over restricted communication channels. We implemented Deep RL methods, comparing Deep Q-Learning, Deep Q-Learning with an auxiliary loss function (which we designed to enable convergence), and Policy Gradient methods. These function approximators were over sequences of unknown length, for which we implemented and compared both Recurrent and Convolutional Neural Networks (pooling over time).

As this work is part of Aaron’s on-going research, the paper submitted for the class project is not publicly available.
entry.summary: Work with Aaron Goodman on used reinforcement learning to discover implicit collusion strategies in the context of an iterated prisoner’s dilemma.

entry.title: Intel RealSense Stereoscopic Depth Cameras
entry.content:
Technical and design details of the Intel RealSense R200 and D400 series

I wrote a paper describing the details of a family of RGBD cameras, ASICs and algorithms produced by Intel. It was submitted and accepted to CCD 2017, a CVPR 2017 Workshop. My coauthors were all senior management at Intel and the paper was written to inform the academic community of issues, challenges and priorities in building stereoscopic depth cameras for production use. We highlight state-of-the-art performance on modern datasets, on certain metrics, along with establishing baselines for new datasets and evaluation metrics for depth cameras in general.
entry.summary: Technical and design details of the Intel RealSense R200 and D400 series

entry.title: Computational models for text summarization
entry.content:
Work with Ludwig Schubert on simplified encoders stages for text summarization.

Abstractive text summarization is a blossoming area of natural language processing research in which short textual summaries are generated from longer input documents. Existing state-of-the-art methods take long time to train, and are limited to functioning on relatively short input sequences. We evaluate neural network architectures with simplified encoder stages, which naturally support arbitrarily long input sequences in a computationally efficient manner.
entry.summary: Work with Ludwig Schubert on simplified encoders stages for text summarization.
